matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS in xss14 Challenge via name Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same XSS vulnerability in the xss14 challenge endpoint. The expected finding identifies 'XSS vulnerability due to incomplete tag filtering allowing script execution' in app.py lines 67-73, while the actual finding confirms 'reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the name parameter' with 'insufficient filtering allowing SVG-based XSS payloads'. Both describe the same attack vector (bypassing incomplete HTML tag filtering), same impact (arbitrary JavaScript execution, cookie theft, session hijacking), and same location (xss14 endpoint). The actual finding provides additional technical detail including the successful POC payload '<svg onload=alert("XSS")>' and confirmation of JavaScript execution.

extra.title: Path Traversal in Werkzeug Static File Handler
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery. While the practical impact is limited in the container environment (most sensitive files return 404), the path traversal mechanism is confirmed functional, allowing navigation outside intended directories using '../' sequences. This is a real vulnerability in Werkzeug 1.0.1 that should be addressed through upgrades and proper path validation.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers
extra.location: HTTP response headers across all endpoints
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery. The absence of all five critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Strict-Transport-Security, Content-Security-Policy) is a valid security misconfiguration that increases attack surface. This represents defense-in-depth weaknesses that should be remediated.

extra.title: Server Version Information Disclosure with Outdated Components
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery. Exposure of 'Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.12' in Server headers aids attacker reconnaissance. The finding correctly identifies both information disclosure and the critical issue of running EOL Python 2.7.12 (end-of-life since January 2020) with no security updates available.

extra.title: Server Software Version Disclosure
extra.assessment: Partial duplicate of finding #4 but with lower severity rating. Both findings address the same Server header disclosure issue. This represents the same underlying vulnerability with different severity assessment, likely due to focusing on information disclosure aspect rather than EOL software risk.

extra.title: Broken XSS25 Challenge - Route Not Registered in Flask Application
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery of broken functionality. While primarily an availability/functionality issue rather than direct security vulnerability, it indicates deployment or configuration problems. The finding correctly identifies that the homepage advertises a link to xss25 but the route returns 404, suggesting incomplete application deployment.

extra.title: Absence of Rate Limiting on Application Endpoints
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery. The absence of rate limiting on all endpoints enables DoS attacks, brute force attempts, and resource exhaustion. Testing confirmed 30+ consecutive requests succeeded without throttling. This is a valid security control gap that should be addressed.

extra.title: Use of End-of-Life Python 2.7.12 with Known Security Vulnerabilities
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery of critical severity. Python 2.7.12 reached EOL on January 1, 2020 and contains numerous unpatched CVEs including CVE-2021-3177 (CVSS 9.8 CRITICAL). Running 5+ year old EOL software with zero security patches available represents significant risk. This is a valid high-severity finding that requires immediate remediation.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting on Application Endpoints
extra.assessment: Duplicate of finding #6. Both findings describe the same absence of rate limiting controls with identical testing methodology (10-30 consecutive requests without throttling). This represents redundant reporting of the same vulnerability.

extra.title: Outdated Werkzeug 1.0.1 with Known CVE-2022-29361 Debug Mode PIN Bypass
extra.location: Werkzeug WSGI server and app.py debug configuration
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery of high severity. Werkzeug 1.0.1 (released 2020) is vulnerable to CVE-2022-29361 (CVSS 7.5 HIGH - debug console PIN bypass), CVE-2023-25577 (CVSS 7.5 HIGH - path traversal), and CVE-2023-46136 (CVSS 5.4 MEDIUM - ReDoS). Combined with confirmed debug mode enabled in code (app.run(debug=True)), this creates remote code execution risk. Valid high-severity finding requiring immediate remediation.

extra.title: State-Changing GET Request Without CSRF Protection in XSS14
extra.assessment: Legitimate new discovery. The xss14 endpoint uses GET method for state-changing operations without CSRF protection, violating HTTP specification (RFC 7231) that GET should be safe and idempotent. Testing confirmed no CSRF tokens and successful cross-origin requests. This enables CSRF attacks and represents poor security architecture, though in context of a CTF challenge application, the real-world impact may be limited.
